switch statement

　The switch statement lets you write if, else if, and else concisely. It has the following syntax:

switch(base_expression)
{
case condition_expression1 :

case condition_expression2 :

:
:

default:

:
:
}

　The base_expression contains an expression, which is evaluated first. Write an expression in condition_expression? next to the case in the block following the switch.
　condition_expression? is evaluated one after another in the block. If the evaluated result is the same as base_expression, execution starts from there. If the condition_expression? does not match, any statements or statements between them are ignored. If they match, case and default are ignored thereafter.
　default: can be omitted, but if default is specified, the statements and statements following default are forcibly executed.
　Write break; to get out of the block. Note that it is common to forget to write a break and execute up to the contents of the next case.


例:
    switch(a)
    {
    case 0:
        inform("a is 0");
        break;
    case 1:
        inform("b is 1");
        break;
    case 2:
        inform("b is 2");
        break;
    default:
        inform("b is not 0, 1 or 2");
    }


    switch(a)
    {
    case 0:
    case 1: // There is no break, so pass here in case 0
        inform("a is 0 or 1");
        break;
    case 2:
        inform("a is 2");
    } // Since there is no default, nothing is executed except for 0 1 2


    switch(a)
    {
    case b+1: // An expression can be specified after the case
        inform("a==b+1");
        break;
    case c+b:
        inform("a==c+b");
    }

    switch(str)
    {
    case "AEIOU": // Strings can also be specified
        type=1;
        break;
    case "ABCDE":
        type=2;
        break;
    }
